prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA 12h
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Spectral line observations imaging CO(1-0) in 30 typical star-forming galaxies at redshifts 0.07 < z < 0.11 in a 16 sq. deg field centered at 12h 0.0d to measure the local cosmic molecular gas content.
At these redshifts, the CO(1-0) line falls between 104.0 - 107.5 GHz, covered by two spectral bands of 1.875 MHz each. The on-source integration time to reach an rms or 2mJy/beam in a 20\,km/s channel at 105\,GHz is 3.6 min per target, thus in total we require a total of 3 hours on this field including overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: In order to consistently estimate the expected CO line flux for our galaxies, we calculated the expected IR luminosity from the observed Herschel SPIRE 250um flux density and then converted this IR luminosity into an expected CO luminosity using a conservative ratio of log(L_{IR}/L'_{CO}) ~ 1.5 based on the observed range for local disk galaxies for our IR luminosity range of log(L_{IR}/L_{sun}) = 10-11. The CO line widths are conservatively based upon the stellar velocity dispersions, with a typical dv ~100 km/s. The CO emitting area is calculated assuming a radial CO length of l_{CO} = 0.2 r_{25} determined from the SDSS photometry. The CO intensity is then determined by dividing by the number of expected beams per CO emitting area (assuming a beam of 2"), leading to an expected average CO emission per galaxy in the range of 10-100 mJy/beam for a single channel. We expect the weakest emission in the disks to be a factor of ~5 less than this. Therefore, to achieve a minimum of ~5 sigma detection in the disks of the faintest objects in our sample, we require an rms of 2 mJy/beam per (binned) 20\,km/s channel. A channel width of 20 km/s will allow us to resolve the kinematics even in face-on systems with small zero intensity line widths of 100-150\,km/s).
The on-source integration time to reach an rms or 2mJy/beam in a 20\,km/s channel at 105 GHz is 3.2 min per target, thus in total we require a total of 6 hours (3 hours per field with 55-60 % of on-source time) to image a complete, well-defined sample of massive galaxies to constrain the local cosmic molecular gas density.
IMAGING: All our objects are chosen to have optical radii 2" < r_{90} < 8" (and with CO radii thought to be smaller than this). This means that all sources will fit within 1/3 of the ALMA primary beam at 105 GHz (~1/3 x 60"), and no sensitivity loss should be experienced. Our maximum recoverable scale is ~25", and thus we are also sensitive to diffuse structure at the scale of our optical disks, while our desired angular resolution of 2" will ensure we have at minimum 2 independent beams across the galactic disks.
CORRELATOR SETUP: Our target resolution is 2'' to resolve the CO emission across the disk for most galaxies in our sample. The configuration C34-2 achieves this resolution and still provides compact baselines sensitive to structures of up to 25'' (i.e. our largest optical disks). We will use 2 correlator units with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and a resolution of 0.975 MHz to cover our target frequency range of 104.04 - 107.55 GHz, and we will bin to our desired resolution of 20 km/s. We will cover the second sideband with two low resolution base bands for more continuum sensitivity and serendipitous detection potential of other lines, such as CN. The required disk space and data rate is small compared to the potential gain.
CALIBRATION AND BANDPASS ACCURACY: Our observations require the standard calibration and bandpass accuracy.
SSCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: As our observations are all ALMA band 3 we have no scheduling constraints, and as variability is not an issue we have no timing constraints.
DATA RATES: Given our observation setup, the expected data rate is 11.2 MB/s which is sufficiently near the expected average of 6 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GAMA 15h
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Spectral line observations imaging CO(1-0) in 30 typical star-forming galaxies at redshifts 0.07 < z < 0.11 in a 16 sq. deg field centered at 15h 0.0d to measure the local cosmic molecular gas content.
At these redshifts, the CO(1-0) line falls between 103.4 - 107.4 GHz, covered by two spectral bands of 1.875 MHz each. The on-source integration time to reach an rms or 2mJy/beam in a 20\,km/s channel at 105\,GHz is 3.6 min per target, thus in total we require a total of 3 hours on this field including overheads.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY: In order to consistently estimate the expected CO line flux for our galaxies, we calculated the expected IR luminosity from the observed Herschel SPIRE 250um flux density and then converted this IR luminosity into an expected CO luminosity using a conservative ratio of log(L_{IR}/L'_{CO}) ~ 1.5 based on the observed range for local disk galaxies for our IR luminosity range of log(L_{IR}/L_{sun}) = 10-11. CORRELATOR SETUP: Our target resolution is 2'' to resolve the CO emission across the disk for most galaxies in our sample. The configuration C34-2 achieves this resolution and still provides compact baselines sensitive to structures of up to 25'' (i.e. our largest optical disks). We will use 2 correlator units with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and a resolution of 0.975 MHz to cover our target frequency range of 103.89 - 107.37 GHz, and we will bin to our desired resolution of 20 km/s. We will cover the second sideband with two low resolution base bands for more continuum sensitivity and serendipitous detection potential of other lines, such as CN. The required disk space and data rate is small compared to the potential gain.
CALIBRATION AND BANDPASS ACCURACY: Our observations require the standard calibration and bandpass accuracy.
SCHEDULING/TIME CONSTRAINTS: As our observations are all ALMA band 3 we have no scheduling constraints, and as variability is not an issue we have no timing constraints.
DATA RATES: Given our observation setup, the expected data rate is 11.2 MB/s which is sufficiently near the expected average of 6 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The molecular gas content of the universe is one of the major drivers of the evolution of the cosmic star formation rate (SFR). Unfortunately, no well-characterized (in stellar/gas/dust mass) local sample exists for comparison to higher redshift populations. Our proposed ALMA observations will remedy this, using band 3 to image the CO(1-0) line in 60 local galaxies (0.07<z<0.11), with stellar masses where the majority of stars are formed: log(M*/M_sun) = 10-11. This proposal presents a paradigm shift for the observations of local galaxies, providing details on molecular gas properties (distribution, kinematics) and mass (total and relative to stellar and dynamical masses). Combined with the extensive ancillary dataset of our chosen GAMA sample (UV to far-IR) we can study the relation of molecular gas to dust (mass, temperature) and stellar properties (SFR, sSFR), as well as the gas depletion times as a function of stellar mass, sSFR and metallicity. This dataset will lead to the first robust determination of the molecular gas content in the local Universe, thus providing the anchor point for all future surveys probing the normal star forming population at high redshift.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of
Department of Physics, New York University
